Dated the 30th October,1950 Sir I have the honour to state that when the Muscat Government was in search of a Director General of Customs in 1946 the Resident in the Persian Gulf addressed the Government of India and asked for the services on lopn of a suitable officer from the Indian Customs Service. The Government of India selected three individuals and while the Resident was on tour in India they were summoned to appear before him at Delhi. I was one of the three and the one finally chosen by him. My first period of secondment to the Muscat Government was for three years from 25th May 1946 to 24th May 1949. Subsequently an extension was offered and accepted by me and sanctioned by the Pakistan Government. I was selected by the Bengal Public Service Commission*^ and appointed to Customs Appraiser Service class II of the Calcutta Customs House on the 5th September 1940 and later confirmed in the appointment from the same date. Prior to partition I opted for service with the Pakistan Government and my option was accepted. My seniority in the Calcutta Customs House was known to me but I have no idea what position has been alloted to me in the Pakistan Customs Service. I understand that on the termination of my deputation here on the 24th May 1951 I shall be posted to the --Karachi Custom House and as my services were loaned through the Consulate and the Residency I should be most grateful if you would be so kind as to ascertain from the Collector of Customs Karachi what my seniority will bo. The Governor General in Council is pleased to sanction the transfer of Mr. M.A.Rashid, an appraiser in the Calcutta Custom House, to Muscat on foreign service as Director General of Customs, with effect from the date he relinquishes charge of his present appointment on the following terms :- Period: For a period of three years in the first instance, of which the first six months will be on probation. Services liable to be terminated without notice on completion of three years and before completion of that period on two months notice by either side. Pay: Rs.550 (Rupees five hundred and fifty) a month ( with free quarters) rising to 650/- (Rupees six hundred and fifty) with an annual increament of Rs.50/- (Rupees fifty) from the date he hands over charge of his duties at Calcutta up to the date of his return. Leave: Under the Rules as applicable to him while in service at the Custom House. Leave salary and pension contributions: In accordance with the rates prescribed by the Governor General in Council from time to time. Travelling allowance : (a) For himself and family as on transfer unaer the Supplementary Rules of the Central Government for journeys to end from Muscat; (b) According to State Rules for journeys if any, performed during foreign service. Foliation: the foliation sequence (used for referencing) commences at the front cover with 1, and terminates at the inside back cover with 17; these numbers are written in pencil, are circled, and are located in the top right corner of the recto side of each folio.

mods.abstract: This file relates to Mohammad Abu Rashid, currently employed as Director-General of Customs in the Sultanate of Muscat and Oman. The correspondence records that Rashid was appointed on deputation from Customs House, Calcutta, and that, prior to partition, while still in Muscat, he had opted for service with the Government of Pakistan. Writing to the Political Agent in October 1950, while still on deputation in Muscat but due to be posted to Karachi the following year, Rashid requests information regarding the level of seniority that he will have in his new post.Other correspondents include the following: the Political Agent and Consul, Muscat; the Persian Gulf Political Residency; the Government of Pakistan's Ministries of Finance and Foreign Affairs.
